title: Cat. 23  Lindsey Row, Chelsea, 1888
publication_title: The Lithographs of James McNeill Whistler: The Digital Edition
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body"> 231888Way: 19  
Levy: 32  
Transfer lithograph, drawn on coarse-grained transfer paper  
Ink color: black  
Signature: printed butterfly, center right  
One state; image size: 124 × 202 mm  
Number of impressions listed by Way: 14  
Printer: Way  
Watermarks: 128, 284  
Posthumous edition: 56 impressions printed by Goulding on 16 February 1904  
Posthumous watermarks: 50–56, 196, 197, 199, 219, 220, 238, 289, 290, 300  
Stone: erased in 1904  
Whistler-Way Letters: 86; apps. I.1, II.3, II.4, III.2, V.1  
Selected Literature: Way and Dennis (1903), p. 85; Wedmore (1906), ill. p. 99  
Lifetime Exhibitions: London 1895–96 (no. 28); New York 1898 (no. 301); London 1898–99 (no. 1988)

This light-filled image of houses on Lindsey Row was drawn near the two residences (at 7 and then 2 Lindsey Row) that Whistler had occupied before he moved into the White House on Tite Street in October 1878. The small trees and overhanging branch appear to be in blossom, suggesting that the drawing was made in spring or early summer. It is probably one of the five images (cat. 23, cat. 24, cat. 25 cat. 26, and cat. 27) listed as having been transferred and proved by Way on 8 June 1888 (app. II.3 and app. II.4).

Disliking the mechanical pattern of the coarse-grained transfer paper, Whistler applied the lithographic crayon lightly and created the shadowed areas with broad parallel hatching. In this way, he both minimized the obtrusive grain of the transfer paper and evoked the airy, sun-drenched atmosphere of the scene.

According to the 1903 inventory, only one impression of this lithograph, which Rosalind Birnie Philip called Lindsey Houses, remained in the artist’s estate.

Chicago: AIC, ivory laid paper (194 × 253 mm), signed; MWC, grayish ivory chine (139 × 213 mm) mounted on off-white plate paper (280 × 382 mm), signed. Glasgow: HAG, cream laid paper (241 × 368 mm). London: BM, grayish white chine (139 × 213 mm) mounted on white plate paper (264 × 356 mm). Washington: FGA, grayish white chine (139 × 212 mm) mounted on white plate paper (280 × 384 mm); NGA, cream wove paper (224 × 286 mm), signed.

Remarks: Other impressions are found in Cleveland, CMA; and New York, MMA.  
Nesta R. Spink, Harriet K. Stratis, Martha Tedeschi

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Way’s misspelling of the title—Lindsay Row, Chelsea—was a common one; the correct spelling, used here, derives from the Earl of Lindsey, whose large house on the river in Chelsea was converted in the eighteenth century into separate dwellings designated 1–7 Lindsey Row.

GUL LB6; transcribed in MacDonald (1988), p. 38.

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 23, only state. The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of the Crown Family in honor of James N. Wood, 2004.548.

</section>
